seg.output: If it were not for the limitations of time, I would have discussed this matter with you, my most upstanding man, for Fortune has overturned me in that moment, so that I have been given no opportunity to either complain of my misfortune to you or to signal to you my grief. To avoid tarrying you any longer than I can in the briefest terms, I will explain my current situation: the Helvetians in our monastery of Fischingen have forced me to leave, causing me no small loss of both better fortune and good time. Now, I must either endure great hunger or seek the help of my friends so as to avert this impending poverty. I cannot imagine a better way to prevent this than if you were to become my patron in my distress. You will surely find men of no mean probity who will work together with you to ensure that I am provided for as best as possible, so long as a suitable period of time for the transaction of this business is agreed upon. Farewell and love me, for I cannot hate you. The rest you will learn from the messenger. Written from the monastery of Fischingen, quickly and in all haste. Your Michael Schlatter to his incomparable master, the renowned Henry Bulinger, bishop of the city of Zurich.
